docs.lead_paragraph: Janitors trying to get their jobs back and to bargain for a new contract have been standing vigil at the gate of Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry for more than a month. Wendy Weiner, a New Rochelle-based organizer at 32 BJ of the Service Employees International Union, affiliated with the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which represents the workers, said that Crystal Blue Cleaning Services, a new contractor brought in by the college to replace MacClean Services of Manhattan, fired the janitors because of their union affiliation.

headline.main: Janitors Air a Dispute At Mercy College Gate

docs.abstract: Janitors, members of Service Employees International Union Local 32 BJ, are staging vigil outside Mercy College in Dobbs Ferry, seeking to get their jobs back and to bargain for new contract; union official says Crystal Blue Cleaning Services, brought in by college to replace MacClean Services of Manhattan, fired janitors because of their union affiliation; college official disagrees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: If it weren't for the steady beat of war drums, health care would be front and center in this fall's political debate. And war or no war, politicians will not be able to avoid it much longer. As John Breaux of Louisiana, long one of the most conservative Senate Democrats, recently told the press, ''The system is collapsing around us.'' That is not hyperbole. Private health insurance premiums are rising at an unsustainable average of about 13 percent per year -- and as much as 25 percent in some areas of the country. Coverage is shrinking, as more employers decide to cap their contributions to health insurance plans and workers find they cannot pay their rapidly expanding share. And with the rise in unemployment, more people are losing what limited coverage they had. Last month, the Census Bureau reported that nearly 1.5 million Americans lost their insurance in 2001.
docs.abstract: Marcia Angell Op-Ed article warns that politicians will not be able to ignore 'collapsing' health care system for much longer; cites unsustainable increases in premiums as private insurers and satellite businesses skim off huge percentages; calls for national single-payer system that would eliminate unnecessary administrative costs, duplication and profits but would not be 'socialized medicine' because doctors and hospitals would remain private (M)
docs.snippet: If it weren't for the steady beat of war drums, health care would be front and center in this fall's political debate. And war or no war, politicians will not be able to avoid it much longer. As John Breaux of Louisiana, long one of the most...

docs.lead_paragraph: For the first time in his three campaigns for governor, George E. Pataki will debate his opponents tomorrow. But he has insisted on including all seven of the candidates actively running, ensuring a cluttered event in which challengers will have a hard time distinguishing themselves. The debate was not put together without a hitch. On Thursday, Mr. Pataki threatened to pull out when the producers at WABC-TV said they wanted to seat him between his two leading opponents, H. Carl McCall and Tom Golisano.

headline.main: Pataki Agrees to Debate, But on a Crowded Stage

docs.abstract: Gov George Pataki agrees to debate challengers in New York campaign, but insists on including all seven, ensuring cluttered event at which leading opponents, H Carl McCall and Tom Golisano, will have hard time distinguishing themselves; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The confirma-tion of President Bush's nominee as commissioner of the Food and Drug Administration, Dr. Mark B. McClellan, encountered a snag because of a dispute about health care for poor pregnant women and their fetuses. A spokeswoman for Senator Jeff Bingaman, Democrat of New Mexico, said he was blocking the nomination to protest a new regulation that lets states classify fetuses as ''unborn children'' eligible for health programs for uninsured low-income people. Advocates of abortion rights welcome expanding prenatal care, but object to giving fetuses separate legal status.

headline.main: National Briefing | Washington: Dispute On Fetuses Stalls Nomination

docs.abstract: Confirmation of Pres Bush's nomination of Dr Mark D McClellan as FDA comr is snagged because of dispute about health care for poor pregnant women and their fetuses; spokeswoman for Sen Jeff Bingaman, New Mexico Democrat, says he is blocking nomination to protest new regulation that lets states classify fetuses as 'unborn children' eligible for health programs for uninsured low-income people; advocates of abortion rights welcome expanding prenatal care, but object to giving fetuses separate legal status; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The state has ended its contract with a company whose janitors have struck and will instead seek a contractor that guarantees health benefits to its employees. The move by Acting Gov. Jane M. Swift prevented picketing of the Statehouse by employees of the company, Unicco. Hundreds of employees are demanding health care, increased pay and full-time work. About 80 janitors, all in Service Employees Union Local 254, clean the Statehouse and three other large buildings in Boston that house state offices. Katherine Zezima (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Strikers Lose Contract

docs.abstract: Massachusetts ends its contract with Unicco, company that supplies janitors to state buildings, and will instead seek contractor that guarantees health benefits to its employees (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: With Congress consumed by Iraq and striving to bring its session to a close, much of the legislative agendas of both parties, including security proposals prompted by the Sept. 11 attacks, is falling by the wayside. The press of time is claiming causes dear to Democrats, like new health care and worker protection initiatives, while Republicans are seeing their push for increased energy production, religion-based social programs and added tax cuts also drop off the legislative schedule.

headline.main: With Time Now Short, Many Bills Fade

docs.abstract: Much of legislative agendas of both Republicans and Democrats, including security proposals prompted by Sept 11 attacks, is falling by wayside as Congress turns its attention to Iraq and strives to bring session to close; focus on foreign policy also gives lawmakers convenient excuse to put off difficult compromises on some issues and avoid others altogether (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, the health insurer, said yesterday that its third-quarter profit was higher than expected as it controlled medical expenses and increased premiums. Aetna said its full-year profit would also beat estimates. The chief executive, John Rowe, is eliminating jobs and has promised to trim $300 million from operating costs this year. The company has shed five million customers who were too expensive to insure and reduced costs by making customers pay more for care. Aetna, which is based in Hartford, announced its forecast after the close of market trading. Its shares, which fell $1.41 and closed at $31.69, traded for more than $35 a share in after-hours trading.

headline.main: AETNA REPORTS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED PROFIT IN QUARTER

docs.abstract: Aetna says third-quarter profit was higher than expected as it controlled medical expenses and increased premiums (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Steve Pearce, a decorated Air Force veteran who says his Democratic opponent is weak on Iraq, is a rarity in the national battle for the House, which seems focused on domestic issues. When State Senator John Arthur Smith, Mr. Pearce's Democratic opponent in New Mexico's Second District -- one of the tossup races expected to determine control of the House -- said last month that President Bush should obtain Congressional backing and seek international backing before taking military action, Mr. Pearce attacked him.

headline.main: Cameo Appearance by Iraq in a New Mexico Race

docs.lead_paragraph: Anthony Mazzocchi, a longtime union official who was a pioneer in the occupational safety movement and the founder of the six-year-old Labor Party, died on Saturday at his home in Washington. He was 76. The cause was pancreatic cancer, Labor Party officials said.

headline.main: Anthony Mazzocchi, 76, Dies; Union Officer and Party Father
